ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Childcare options and the impact of COVID on these already limited options.

I learned a great deal about the child care system in the United States. I learned about how much demand there is for it, what the workforce looks like, and why it currently stands as a rather patchwork system.
I completely changed the way that I view early childhood education

I learned about many of the major questions in the field of early education, such as what types of early childhood education centers exist, how centers are financed, who pays for early education, and the quality of the current system.
I learned so much about all aspects of the early childhood education field, including psychological aspects of child development and policy aspects of funding + changing public will.
I learned a lot about the state of child care in America today. I also learned a lot about the relationship between child care and child development and child care and the economy.

Understanding the factors that contribute to child care policy in the US. Covered topics like diversity of the childcare workforce, affordability and funding of childcare, economics of childcare, universal child care, quality early childcare and pedagogies, etc

I learned so so much from taking this class. I was exposed to the whole world of policy in regards to childcare, including how it is funded, and which children get priority. I learned all about the state of childcare as well as how important high-quality childcare is for all kinds of specific aspects of child development.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths -- Jess and Janna are PHENOMENAL instructors. They care so deeply about the materials they present and the students of the class. The community they fostered over Zoom was like no other. I genuinely felt like I had made a connection with them and several of my classmates despite the fact that I had never met them in person. The instructors are incredibly discussion facilitators -- I always found it easy to contribute to the conversation. 
Weaknesses -- none!!

strengths: Jess and Janna made every class so much fun and extremely knowledgeable about current issues and policies in early childhood education! I really enjoyed the guest speakers and weekly discussions. 
weaknesses: I wish we had received more feedback on the papers that we had written throughout the term. It was difficult to know what to work on without specific feedback.

Strengths: Jess and Janna are the nicest people you'll meet and are committed to your learning about the field. 
Weaknesses: Things got a bit repetitive after awhile since it seemed to always go back to the same core issues and we didn't necessarily have new solutions. Maybe introduce the final project a little earlier + include peer revision?

I thought that some of the strengths of this course were how the assignments and readings were structured, the instructors, and the class structure. I felt that all of these elements were able to combine in a way where I was able to learn from each reading and assignment and then in class learn from my peers and Janna and Jessica, the instructors. One of the areas that I thought could be a little different was the variety of the readings, especially in the first half. It felt like a lot of the readings hit on aspects of the same thing, which was good for reinforcement, but I think my understanding of the subject might have been benefitted by an article with a broader overview of the mechanics of the system. Funding was something I felt especially confused about the specifics of until a lot later in the course.
SUCH an incredible class that really thrives because every student cares so much about the material and always has something valuable to share.
Very engaging, interesting content, amazing professors, and worthwhile assignments that really expand on the content and allow for individual exploration.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The check-ins that they used were really great as a primer for opening us all up for the discussion. I think many professors try to do check-ins that come across as cheesy or disingenuine, but that was never the case with Jess and Janna. The check-in activities they did really helped strengthen our class community.

I thought the course was great at adapting to online learning. I really appreciated Jess and Janna's activity to start each class. I also liked that they tried to simulate a real class by encouraging smaller discussion while eating snacks :) By far my favorite online class
Jess and Janna care so much about your well-being as a person and student, especially during the pandemic. They were always so accommodating and made learning so enjoyable and rewarding.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely!! Especially if you are an EDST Scholar. I think we focus so much on K-12 education and forget about the very important work happening in the early childhood education realm! If you are not an EDST Scholar, please take this class too! During the very first class, you will come to learn how much of an impact child care has had on your own life!
Yes!!

I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in early childhood education, as well as to those who are more generally interested in how early education is closely knit into many aspects of society.  The course did not give as much feedback on essays as I had hoped, but nevertheless was a very fun class.

CW: gun violence, suicide, hate crimes

Yes! I learned a lot about a field I wouldn't have learned about elsewhere, and the fact that you're learning from two people who have worked in the field for decades is an unparalleled experience. The workload is super reasonable/manageable and your classmates are fun and kind. I hear there's weekly snacks when the class is taught in person soooo...! 

Something that really stuck out to me this year was Jess and Janna's response after the shithole month that included the Atlanta spa shootings as well as Yale's own failures responding to a suicide on campus. We did a checkin like normal and everyone was feeling understandably terrible. They were really good at reading the Zoom room and let the checkin go on for longer than usual so we could talk about our feelings--much of which included grief, anger, frustration, etc. that we couldn't voice elsewhere. Instead of continuing class, they decided to give us the option to spend the rest of the two hours holding space for each other and talking about how we were feeling. We were also allowed to leave class early, and we made up the content in a future week. The space was really healing for myself and likely many classmates, and I appreciate that they were so flexible and empathetic to us, first seeing us as humans before anything else. I felt supported, loved, heard, and cared for--something that they're so good at doing every week.

I would HIGHLY recommend this course to another student! It's one of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale. Anyone with an interest in the lives of children would find this course fascinating. For anyone with an interest in any level of the education system, this class is more than fascinating: it's essential. I didn't realize until taking this course how fundamental child care and early learning are to a child's outcomes and how inequalities in this early system create inequalities later on. Even if you do know those thing, this class is a great way to expand that knowledge. Additionally, Janna and Jessica are lovely.
Yes! This is an important topic and the type of people who take this course are super cool.
YES YES YES. Jess and Janna are gems and know so much about childcare and the workforce as a result of their work with All Our Kin. Such a pleasure to get to learn with them and exchange ideas.
Yes, 100%! if you are at all interested in childhood, child development, education, early disparities in life, and/or policy relating to children this is such a good class for you.
